headline1: Paid Notice: Deaths   WANTZ, DIANA DILWORTH
headline2: Paid Notice: Deaths   WANTZ, DIANA DILWORTH
snippet: WANTZ--Diana Dilworth. On August 27, 2005. Beloved wife of the late George E. Wantz, M.D. Mother of David Hoguet of Cincinnati, OH and Diana Hoguet of Boulder, CO. Grandmother of Jennifer and Laura. Sister of the late J. Richardson Dilworth. Memor...
lead_paragraph: WANTZ--Diana Dilworth. On August 27, 2005. Beloved wife of the late George E. Wantz, M.D. Mother of David Hoguet of Cincinnati, OH and Diana Hoguet of Boulder, CO. Grandmother of Jennifer and Laura. Sister of the late J. Richardson Dilworth. Memorial service Saturday, September 10 at St. James Church, 71st and Madison Ave. Donations may be made to Association of Frontotemporal Dementia, 100 North St, Ste 600, Phila., PA 19103 (www.ftd-picks.org for donation form).

headline1: Studies Tie Abnormal Protein Buildup to Dementia
headline2: Studies Tie Abnormal Protein Buildup to Dementia
snippet: Scientists think that abnormal protein deposits inside brain cells cause frontotemporal degeneration.
lead_paragraph: “If there’s something to be done, I want to be in on the ground floor,” said Elizabeth, 67, a woman participating in studies of frontotemporal degeneration at the University of California, San Francisco.

headline1: The Challenges of a Dementia Patient
headline2: The Challenges of a Dementia Patient
snippet: Readers offer suggestions and personal stories about caring for someone with dementia.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline1: When Illness Makes a Spouse a Stranger
headline2: When Illness Makes a Spouse a Stranger
snippet: Like many others, Ruth French finds herself grappling with her spouse’s frontotemporal dementia, a group of brain diseases that eat away at personality and language.
lead_paragraph: He threw away tax documents, got a ticket for trying to pass an ambulance and bought stock in companies that were obviously in trouble. Once a good cook, he burned every pot in the house. He became withdrawn and silent, and no longer spoke to his wife over dinner. That same failure to communicate got him fired from his job at a consulting firm.

headline1: In Love and Loss
snippet: Michael French has frontotemporal dementia, for which there is no treatment. As his condition deteriorated, his wife, Ruth, had to move him to a nursing home, where she spends most days.
lead_paragraph: Michael French has frontotemporal dementia, for which there is no treatment. As his condition deteriorated, his wife, Ruth, had to move him to a nursing home, where she spends most days.

headline1: Michael French, Who Battled a Rare Dementia, Dies at 73
headline2: One Mind’s Long Decay Finally Ends
snippet: Michael French, who struggled with the brain disease frontotemporal dementia, diagnosed in 2007, died at a Manhattan nursing home.
lead_paragraph: Michael French, whose long struggle with the brain disease frontotemporal dementia was the subject of a 2012 New York Times article and video, died Nov. 30 at a nursing home in Manhattan. He was 73.

headline1: When They Don’t Know They Are Ill
snippet: Frequently a result of dementia, anosognosia is the inability to recognize one’s own impairment — a phenomenon caregivers know too well.
lead_paragraph: Soon after his wife was diagnosed with frontotemporal dementia, Bill Floyd consulted a neurologist who had been a member of his church. People with this illness don’t know they have it, the doctor warned. They don’t understand that anything is wrong.

headline1: Your Brain, Your Disease, Your Self
headline2: Your Brain, Your Disease, Your Self
snippet: What kind of neural damage threatens your identity — and why?
lead_paragraph: WHEN does the deterioration of your brain rob you of your identity, and when does it not?

headline1: Review: ‘Looks Like Laury, Sounds Like Laury,’ a Documentary of Dementia
headline2: A Devastating Vanishing Act in Dementia’s Grip
snippet: The film, on the World Channel’s “America ReFramed” series, is an unflinching case study of a woman in her 40s who has a neurological condition called frontotemporal dementia.
lead_paragraph: “You try to think about a lot of things before you make a commitment,” Eric Sacks says during a documentary about his wife, “but you don’t think about something like this.”

headline1: Terry Jones of Monty Python Has Dementia, His Family Says
headline2: Monty Python Member Said to Have Dementia
snippet: The actor, 74, is best known for his roles in the British comedy troupe and as a director or writer of works like “Life of Brian” and “Monty Python and the Holy Grail.”
lead_paragraph: Terry Jones, an original member of Monty Python, has a form of dementia that is affecting his ability to communicate, his family said in a statement.

headline1: Food Memories of Travels to France
headline2: To Appreciate: A Cookbook of Memories From Travels to France
snippet: “Cooking With Adrienne” chronicles the trips and recipes of a gastronome who has degenerative dementia.
lead_paragraph: Gastronomy, and not just the Eiffel Tower, has always lured some travelers to France. Adrienne Zausner; her husband, Martin Zausner; and their friend Joan M. Harper were among those gastronomes, dining at Michelin three-star restaurants the way safarigoers checked the “Big Five” off their lists. Ms. Zausner went beyond exquisite dinners by befriending chefs, cooking with them and serving their recipes at home. Now, afflicted with primary progressive aphasia, a type of degenerative dementia, Ms. Zausner can no longer prepare lobster in Champagne sauce from L’Auberge de L’Ill or salmon in sorrel sauce from Jean Troisgros. Ms. Harper has assembled a cookbook of recipes, stories about Ms. Zausner’s travels and useful kitchen advice. Ten percent of the proceeds goes to the Association for Frontotemporal Degeneration: “Cooking With Adrienne: A Story of Friendship and Food” by Joan M. Harper (Harper Publications, $19.99), cookingwithadrienne.com.

headline1: Ending Medical Tax Break Could Be a ‘Gut Punch’ to the Middle Class
headline2: Families Fear Costs if Medical Tax Break Ends
snippet: The tax deduction on medical expenses helps millions of Americans cope with high health care costs. The Republican tax proposal would eliminate it.
lead_paragraph: Suzanne Hollack tried to care for her husband at home after he was diagnosed with frontotemporal dementia at age 69. But it got to the point where she couldn’t take a shower for fear he would stray out of the house.

headline1: The Brain Fog of Menopause
headline2: The Brain Fog of Menopause Can Burn Off
snippet: ‘Menopause-related cognitive impairment happens to women in their 40s and 50s, women in the prime of life who suddenly have the rug pulled out from under them,’ an expert says.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Gayatri Devi’s patient, a 55-year-old former headmistress, had good reason to be distraught. The woman had a yearlong history of progressive memory loss and behavioral problems and was referred to Dr. Devi, a neurologist, with a possible diagnosis of frontotemporal dementia.

headline1: Leading an Active Life With a Diagnosis of Dementia
headline2: After a Dementia Diagnosis, Living Life to the Fullest
snippet: As the number of people with dementia rises, those with early stages of the ailment are pursuing fulfilling lives and making plans for future care.
lead_paragraph: Laurie Scherrer was a workaholic sales executive when she began forgetting customers and losing her ability to perform simple math calculations. Five years ago, at age 55, she learned she has early-onset Alzheimer’s disease and frontotemporal dementia.

headline1: What if My Mother’s Extramarital Cravings Are Linked to Dementia?
headline2: What If My Mother’s Extramarital Cravings Are Linked to Dementia?
snippet: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on how to address a parent’s —and a sibling’s — apparent mental decline.
lead_paragraph: My mother is in her mid-50s, which is the time at which people can develop frontotemporal degeneration (FTD), a form of dementia she is at risk for. Symptoms of FTD include a lack of inhibition or social tact and unusual verbal, physical or sexual behavior. My father and I have at times worried that she may be exhibiting the beginnings of other symptoms. A few years ago, she consulted with a doctor, but no diagnosis was made. I think it is pertinent to note that there is currently no cure for FTD.

headline1: The Loneliness of Frontotemporal Dementia
snippet: Since areas that dictate personality rather than memory are the first to suffer, people with the disease usually land on a therapist’s couch long before finding their way to a neurologist.
lead_paragraph: At 66, Bob Karger was losing language. It was not the tip-of-the-tongue feeling that melts when you recall a sought-after word. He had lost the connection between sounds and meaning — the way ba-na-na recalls a soft, yellow fruit or ea-gle calls to mind a large bird of prey. In a recent conversation, he had thought acorns grew on pine trees.

headline1: ‘Amazing, Isn’t It?’ Long-Sought Blood Test for Alzheimer’s in Reach
headline2: Blood Test Is ‘Big Step Forward’ In Early Detection of Alzheimer’s
snippet: Scientists say such tests could be available in a few years, speeding research for treatments and providing a diagnosis for dementia patients who want to know if they have Alzheimer’s disease.
lead_paragraph: A newly developed blood test for Alzheimer’s has diagnosed the disease as accurately as methods that are far more expensive or invasive, scientists reported on Tuesday, a significant step toward a longtime goal for patients, doctors and dementia researchers. The test has the potential to make diagnosis simpler, more affordable and widely available.

headline1: Stalked by the Fear That Dementia Is Stalking You
snippet: Testing for Alzheimer’s disease and other forms of dementia is hardly foolproof, and could even backfire.
lead_paragraph: Do I know I’m at risk for developing dementia? You bet.

headline1: Watching My Son Grow, and My Mom Return to Childhood
snippet: My brilliant mom was diagnosed with dementia when my son was a baby. For a time, their interests and abilities matched exactly.
lead_paragraph: This story was originally published on Jan. 14, 2020 in NYT Parenting.

headline1: She Bought a Truck on eBay, Then Forgot It. A Dementia Diagnosis Came Later.
snippet: Impulsive purchases, out-of-control spending: These behaviors can be early signs of Alzheimer’s disease or other cognitive decline.
lead_paragraph: After Maria Turner’s minivan was totaled in an accident a dozen years ago, she grew impatient waiting for the insurance company to process the claim.
